title: NK-92 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Protocol ID: HUM-NK92-CULTURE-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-21

title: NK-92 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 1 – Medium and reagent preparation

Prepare complete NK-92 medium:

RPMI 1640

10% heat-inactivated FCS

1% Pen/Strep


Prepare IL-2 working aliquots.
Supplement complete medium with IL-2 immediately before use:

200 IU/mL final (or your lab-validated concentration).

Pre-warm:

NK-92 complete medium + IL-2

PBS (if washing is needed)
to 37 °C.








Note



IL-2 is unstable when stored in complete medium. Always add fresh, immediately before feeding.

title: NK-92 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 2 – Thawing NK-92 cells

Remove a cryovial from liquid nitrogen and place immediately in a 37 °C water bath.
Gently swirl until only a small ice crystal remains.
Disinfect the vial and transfer to a biosafety cabinet.
Transfer the contents to a 15 mL tube containing 9–10 mL pre-warmed medium without IL-2 to dilute DMSO.
Centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min.
Carefully aspirate supernatant.
Gently resuspend the pellet in 10–15 mL NK-92 complete medium with IL-2.
Transfer cells to a T25 or T75 flask and incubate at 37 °C, 5% CO₂.







Warning



Do not expose thawed cells to DMSO for more than a few minutes; wash immediately after thawing.

title: NK-92 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 3 – Routine culture and passaging

Recommended density

Maintain cultures between 2 × 10⁵ and 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL.



Procedure

Gently pipette or swirl flask to resuspend cells uniformly.
Remove an aliquot for counting and viability.
If density exceeds 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL, split culture:

Remove part of the culture (e.g., ½–¾ volume).
Replace with fresh NK-92 medium + IL-2.

Restore cultures to 2–3 × 10⁵ cells/mL.
Return flasks to incubator.



Full medium change for stressed cultures

Collect cells and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min.
Aspirate depleted medium.
Resuspend cells in fresh complete NK-92 medium + IL-2.







Note



Fresh IL-2 medium is essential after any decline in viability; NK-92 responds rapidly to improved culture conditions.

title: NK-92 Cell Line Culture Protocol
section: Step 4 – Preparing NK-92 cells for experiments
text:
Step 4 – Preparing NK-92 cells for experiments

For functional assays, activate cultures 24 hours before experiments using:

Fresh NK-92 complete medium + IL-2


Seed cultures at defined densities (e.g., 2–3 × 10⁵ cells/mL).
Avoid using NK-92 beyond a set passage number (e.g., <20 passages post-thaw).

title: NK-92 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 5 – Cryopreservation of NK-92 cells

Freezing medium

90% FCS + 10% DMSO, or

Mix cell suspension 1:1 with BUF-GEN-FREEZE-MIX-001 for a final 10% DMSO freezing medium.



Procedure

Harvest NK-92 cells during exponential growth.
Centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min.
Resuspend cells at 5–10 × 10⁶ cells/mL in freezing medium.
Aliquot 1 mL per labelled cryovial.
Place into a controlled-rate freezing container (Mr Frosty).
Freeze at −70/−80 °C for ≥12 hours.
Transfer to liquid nitrogen for long-term storage.

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Protocol ID: HUM-KHYG1-CULTURE-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-21

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 1 – Medium and reagent preparation

Prepare KHYG-1 complete medium based on R10 (BUF-GEN-R10-MED-001):

RPMI 1640

10% heat-inactivated FCS

1% Pen/Strep


Prepare IL-2 stock according to manufacturer’s instructions.
Immediately before use, supplement complete medium with IL-2:

Final concentration: 100–200 IU/mL (use a lab-validated concentration consistently).

Pre-warm:

KHYG-1 complete medium + IL-2

PBS (if washing is needed)
to 37 °C.








Note



IL-2 should not be stored long-term in medium; add fresh to pre-warmed R10 immediately before feeding or splitting cultures.

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 2 – Thawing KHYG-1 cells

Remove a cryovial of KHYG-1 cells from liquid nitrogen and immediately place it in a 37 °C water bath.
Gently swirl the vial until only a small ice crystal remains (1–2 min).
Disinfect the outside of the vial with 70% ethanol and transfer to a biosafety cabinet.
Transfer the vial contents to a 15 mL tube containing 9–10 mL pre-warmed KHYG-1 complete medium without IL-2 to dilute DMSO.
Centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at room temperature.
Carefully aspirate the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellet.
Resuspend the cell pellet gently in 10–15 mL pre-warmed KHYG-1 complete medium with IL-2.
Transfer cells to an appropriate flask (e.g. T25 or T75).
Place the flask in a 37 °C, 5% CO₂ incubator.







Warning



Do not leave cells in freezing medium (DMSO-containing) after thawing. Wash promptly to minimise DMSO toxicity.

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 3 – Routine culture and passaging

Recommended density range

Maintain cultures between approximately 2 × 10⁵ and 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL.



Monitoring and splitting

Gently resuspend the culture by pipetting up and down or gently swirling the flask.
Remove a small aliquot for counting and viability assessment.
If the cell density exceeds 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL, split the culture:

Remove a defined volume of culture (e.g. half to three-quarters of the flask volume).
Replace with an equal volume of fresh pre-warmed KHYG-1 medium with IL-2.
This corresponds to approximately a 1:2–1:4 split, depending on growth.

Aim to re-establish cultures at 2–3 × 10⁵ cells/mL after splitting.
Return flasks to the incubator (37 °C, 5% CO₂).



Medium change for lower-density cultures

If cells are at acceptable density but medium appears acidic or exhausted:

Gently resuspend cells.

Transfer to a 15 mL tube and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min.

Aspirate supernatant and resuspend in fresh medium with IL-2 at the desired density.

Return to flask and incubator.








Note



Maintain consistent IL-2 concentrations at each passage and medium change. Record IL-2 lot numbers for traceability.

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
section: Step 4 – Short-term maintenance and experimental setup
text:
Step 4 – Short-term maintenance and experimental setup

For experiments, seed KHYG-1 cells at a defined density consistent with experimental requirements (e.g. 2–3 × 10⁵ cells/mL).
Use fresh medium with IL-2 on the day before and the day of the experiment to ensure cells are in active growth phase.
Avoid using cultures older than a defined passage number (e.g. >20–25 passages post-thaw) for critical experiments; restart from frozen stock as needed.

title: KHYG-1 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 5 – Cryopreservation of KHYG-1 cells

Freezing medium

Standard freezing medium for KHYG-1:

90% FCS + 10% DMSO
or

Cell suspension in R10 mixed 1:1 with BUF-GEN-FREEZE-MIX-001 (2× freezing medium) to yield final 10% DMSO.




Freezing procedure

Ensure KHYG-1 cells are in exponential growth phase (healthy, non-overgrown cultures).
Transfer the culture to a 15 or 50 mL tube and centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min.
Aspirate the supernatant and gently resuspend the pellet in freezing medium at 5–10 × 10⁶ cells/mL.
Aliquot 1 mL of cell suspension per labelled cryovial (include cell line name, passage number, date, and your initials).
Place vials into a controlled-rate freezing container (e.g. Mr Frosty).
Freeze at −70/−80 °C for at least 12–24 hours.
Transfer vials to liquid nitrogen for long-term storage.







Warning



Avoid extended handling of cells at room temperature in freezing medium; DMSO is toxic and should be minimised outside of the controlled freezing process.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-SPL-NK-PROLIF-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-21

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 1 – Preparations on the day before sort
text:
Step 1 – Preparations on the day before sort

Determine:

Mouse genotypes (e.g. WT, CD160 KO, IFNAR1 KO, etc.).
Number of mice per genotype and per experimental group.
Number of timepoints and replicates for the proliferation assay.

Assign mice to the experiment in PyRAT (or equivalent animal management system) and record a cohort ID.
Export the list of mice and provide it to the animal facility (e.g. Kathrin) as required.
Prepare sort collection tubes:

For each sorted population (e.g. total NK, CD160⁺ NK, CD160⁻ NK), prepare 15 mL Falcon tubes.
Add 2–3 mL FCS to each tube.
Place tubes on a roller at 4 °C (cold room) or in the fridge overnight to allow coating.

Prepare 50 mL Falcon tubes with 1× PBS for spleen harvest:

One tube per mouse or per pooled group (as per experimental design).
Store at 4 °C until use.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 2 – Preparations on the day of sort: spleen harvest
text:
Step 2 – Preparations on the day of sort: spleen harvest

Bring prepared PBS tubes and transport containers to the animal facility.
Remove cages of mice assigned to the experiment:

Pool mice in groups as required (e.g. groups of 10 within a cage).
Sacrifice mice (e.g. in CO₂ chamber) according to institutional guidelines.

Harvest spleens:

Place each spleen into a 50 mL tube containing cold PBS (5–10 mL).
Keep tubes on ice during transport back to the lab.

Refer to the relevant SOP for detailed organ harvest and splenocyte isolation, if needed.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
text:
Step 3 – Preparation of splenocyte suspensions

In a biosafety cabinet, transfer each spleen to a sterile Petri dish containing cold PBS.
Gently homogenise the spleen through a suitable cell strainer (e.g. 70 µm) using the plunger of a 5 or 10 mL syringe into a 50 mL tube.
Rinse the strainer with additional PBS to maximise cell recovery.
Centrifuge at ~400–500 g for 5 min at 4 °C.
Discard supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet in FACS buffer (BUF-GEN-FACS-BUF-001) or PBS, as appropriate for counting.
Count splenocytes and record total cell numbers.







Note



A rough guideline used in the original SOP is ~1 × 10⁸ splenocytes per mouse. This can be used for initial planning but always verify by counting.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 4 – NK cell isolation from spleen
text:
Step 4 – NK cell isolation from spleen
Follow the instructions of the magnetic NK cell isolation kit (e.g. EasySep Mouse NK cell isolation kit) and the recommendations for temperature and volumes.

Calculate the total splenocyte count and volume needed for isolation:

For example, if using 14 spleens and assuming ~1 × 10⁸ cells per spleen, plan for ~1.4 × 10⁹ splenocytes.
Adjust volumes and kit reagent amounts accordingly.

Adjust the splenocyte suspension to 1 × 10⁸ cells/mL in FACS buffer or kit-specified buffer at room temperature.
For comparison of NK cells from two genotypes (e.g. WT vs CD160 KO):

Perform complete NK isolation as per the kit instructions for each genotype (full recommended reagent volumes per mL of cells).

For experiments requiring NK subsets (e.g. CD160⁺ vs CD160⁻ NK from WT mice):

Perform a pre-enrichment step:

Use the same kit but with half the indicated volume of isolation cocktail and magnetic beads per mL of cells (to enrich but not fully deplete other cells).


Keep reagents, buffers, and cells at room temperature during the magnetic isolation, as recommended by the kit.







Warning



Deviating from the manufacturer’s temperature recommendations (e.g. performing kit steps on ice instead of room temperature) can substantially reduce NK cell yield and purity.



After isolation or pre-enrichment, resuspend NK-enriched cells in PBS for CellTrace staining (see Step 5).

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 5 – CellTrace staining of NK cells
text:
Step 5 – CellTrace staining of NK cells
This step uses CellTrace Violet (CTV) or CellTrace Blue (CTB) to track divisions.

Count enriched NK cells and calculate the volume needed for staining.
Resuspend NK cells at 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL in PBS (no FCS).
Prepare CTV or CTB according to the manufacturer’s instructions:

Reconstitute the vial in DMSO to create a concentrated stock.

Stain NK cells:

For CTV: use a final concentration corresponding to 1:5000 of the stock (as used in the original SOP).

For CTB: use a final concentration corresponding to 1:1000 of the stock.

Incubate at 37 °C for 15 min, protected from light.
Controls:

Before staining, remove aliquots of cells for:

Unstained control.
Live/dead-only control.

After CTV/CTB staining, remove an aliquot for:

CTV/CTB single-stain control.


Quench and wash:

Add complete NK medium (BUF-MUS-NK-MED-001; cRPMI with supplements and IL-15 omitted at this stage or added as per your lab practice) to a volume sufficient to quench the dye.
Centrifuge at ~400 g for 5 min.
Discard supernatant and resuspend in fresh NK medium or FACS buffer as required for subsequent surface staining.








Warning



Incorrect CTV/CTB concentration or prolonged staining can cause toxicity and alter NK cell behaviour. Always work within titrated ranges and avoid exceeding 15 min at 37 °C.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 6 – Surface staining for sorting (if sorting NK subsets)
text:
Step 6 – Surface staining for sorting (if sorting NK subsets)
If sorting CD160⁺ and CD160⁻ NK subsets or other NK subsets, perform surface staining after CTV/CTB labelling.

Prepare surface staining master mixes in FACS buffer (BUF-GEN-FACS-BUF-001), including:

Fc block (e.g. 1:200).

Surface antibodies for NK identification and subset discrimination (e.g. NK1.1, NKp46, CD3, CD160, etc.).

Live/dead dye, if not already integrated earlier.

Stain up to 5 × 10⁶ cells in 50 µL surface staining mix per tube.
Incubate for 30 min at 4 °C, protected from light.
Add ~4× the staining volume of FACS buffer to wash.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 min, discard supernatant.
Resuspend the cell pellet at 10–15 × 10⁶ cells/mL in PBS for sorting (e.g. for a 70 µm nozzle).
Prepare single-colour controls:

Single-stain controls for each fluorochrome in PBS.
Live/dead controls in beads and/or cells.

Keep all stained cells and controls cold (4 °C or on ice) and protected from light until sorting.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
text:
Step 7 – Sorting and collection

Set up the cell sorter (e.g. BD FACS Aria) with the appropriate nozzle (e.g. 70 µm) and sorting strategy for NK cells and subsets.
Use FCS-coated collection tubes prepared in Step 1:

Add an appropriate volume of NK medium (BUF-MUS-NK-MED-001) to each tube before sorting.

Sort NK populations:

For total NK proliferation: sort or gate total NK cells as required.

For subset proliferation (e.g. CD160⁺ vs CD160⁻): sort each subset into separate collection tubes.

Keep collection tubes at 4 °C or room temperature as appropriate and move them to the incubator as soon as sorting is complete.







Tip



Monitor sort purity and yield during the run to ensure that enough events are collected for the planned timepoints and replicates.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
section: Step 8 – In vitro culture and proliferation assay
text:
Step 8 – In vitro culture and proliferation assay

After sorting, count the NK cell populations (e.g. using a microscope or automated cell counter).
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 min and resuspend in NK medium (BUF-MUS-NK-MED-001) supplemented with IL-15.

Add IL-15 to a final concentration of 100 IU/mL immediately before plating.

Plate sorted NK cells in suitable culture plates (e.g. 96-well U- or flat-bottom plates):

Typical seeding density: 20–50 × 10³ cells per well in 200 µL NK medium + IL-15.

Adjust based on yield and number of timepoints.

Culture conditions:

Incubate plates at 37 °C, 5 % CO₂.
Include:

“Day 0” samples (can be fixed immediately after sorting).

Multiple timepoints (e.g. day 2, 3, 4, etc.).


Controls:

Unstimulated NK cells (IL-15 only).

NK cells with additional stimuli, if desired (cytokines, co-stimulation, etc.).

CTV/CTB single-stain and unstained controls (can be fixed early).

For each selected timepoint:

Harvest NK cells from the wells.
Optionally stain for additional surface markers (using standard FACS buffer and staining conditions).
Fix cells in 4 % PFA or Histofix as per your lab standard.








Note



The original SOP notes that Day 0 populations and single-stain controls can be fixed immediately for reference; subsequent timepoints should be acquired using the same cytometer settings as Day 0.

title: In vitro NK Cell Proliferation Assay Using CellTrace Dyes
text:
Step 9 – Acquisition and analysis

Acquire all timepoints on the same flow cytometer (e.g. Cytek Aurora) using:

The same voltage/PMT settings.
Consistent compensation and gating strategy.

When possible, use:

Counting beads and/or

A fixed acquisition volume and flow rate.

Analyse CellTrace dilution profiles for each NK population:

Determine the number of divisions.

Calculate proliferation indices and division indices as required.

Compare genotypes or conditions (e.g. WT vs KO, CD160⁺ vs CD160⁻).

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-LIV-DIG-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-20

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 1 – Liver harvest and perfusion

Euthanise the mouse using CO₂ asphyxiation or another approved method (ensure compatibility if cardiac puncture is also performed in the experiment).
Weigh the mouse and record the body weight.
Perform a midline incision to open the abdominal cavity and expose the liver and portal vein.
Load a 5 mL syringe with Liver Digestion Buffer and attach a 27 G needle.
Perfuse the liver through the Inferior vena cava with approximately 2 mL Liver Digestion Buffer per mouse, allowing blood and perfusate to drain into a petri dish or waste beaker.







Warning



Handle needles and sharps carefully and dispose of them directly into an approved sharps container after perfusion.



Excise the liver and place it on filter paper to blot excess blood and buffer.
Weigh the liver and record the weight.
Transfer the liver to a 10 cm petri dish and mince it roughly into small fragments using scissors or scalpels.
Transfer the minced liver pieces into the pre-labeled 50 mL tube containing 3 mL Liver Digestion Buffer.

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 2 – Enzymatic digestion

Place the 50 mL tubes containing minced liver in 3 mL Liver Digestion Buffer on a 37 °C benchtop shaker.
Incubate at 37 °C, 250 rpm for 30 minutes.







Note



Ensure tubes are securely capped and properly balanced in the shaker to avoid leakage and uneven mixing.

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
section: STEP 3 – Mechanical dissociation and first wash
text:
STEP 3 – Mechanical dissociation and first wash

After the 30-minute digestion, add FACS/MACS Buffer to each 50 mL tube to a total volume of 25 mL.
Place a 70 μm cell strainer into a 10 cm petri dish.
Pour the entire content of one liver tube onto the cell strainer, ensuring all tissue fragments are transferred.
Using the back of a 5 mL syringe plunger, mechanically dissociate the liver through the strainer until no visible large fragments remain.
Use a transfer pipette to:

Rinse remaining material on the strainer with FACS buffer.
Help pass residual clumps through the mesh.

Once the sample is fully dissociated:

Pour the cell suspension from the petri dish back into the corresponding 50 mL tube.

Add additional FACS buffer to the petri dish:

Dab the bottom of the strainer in the buffer to wash off remaining cells.
Rinse the syringe plunger in the buffer to recover residual cells.
Use a transfer pipette to collect all remaining liquid and return it to the 50 mL tube.

Repeat steps 2–7 for each liver.
Top up each 50 mL tube to 50 mL with FACS buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes (4 °C recommended).







Warning



Cell pellets from digested livers are often loose. When discarding supernatant by pouring, use a slow, controlled motion and avoid abrupt shaking or flicking.



Carefully discard supernatant by pouring.
Top up each tube again to 50 mL with FACS buffer.
Resuspend pellets by gentle inversion or a brief controlled shake.
Centrifuge again at 400 g for 5 minutes (4 °C recommended).

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 4 – 33% Percoll purification

During the second centrifugation, prepare 33% Percoll Solution according to its buffer protocol (BUF-PERC-33-v1.0).
Aliquot 10 mL of 33% Percoll Solution into pre-labeled 15 mL Falcon tubes, one tube per liver.
After the centrifugation in STEP 3:

Carefully discard the supernatant from each 50 mL tube by pouring.

Use the remaining dead volume in each tube to resuspend the cell pellet with a transfer pipette.
Transfer the resuspended cells into the corresponding 15 mL tube containing 10 mL 33% Percoll Solution.
Gently invert the 15 mL tubes to ensure an even cell suspension in Percoll.
Centrifuge the Percoll suspensions at 1700 rpm for 15 minutes at room temperature

Acceleration: 9

Brake: 1 (minimal braking to preserve gradient).








Note



After the Percoll spin, a hepatocyte-rich layer typically floats on top, while a lymphocyte + erythrocyte pellet forms at the bottom.



Prepare several layers of paper towels near a sink or waste container.
In one smooth motion, pour off the hepatocyte layer and supernatant from each 15 mL tube.
Keep tubes inverted and gently dab the tube openings on paper towels to wick off residual liquid, avoiding disturbance of the pellet.

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 5 – RBC lysis

Add 0.5 mL HybriMax RBC lysis buffer (or equivalent; see BUF-RBC-HYB-v1.0) directly to each pellet in the 15 mL tubes.
Pipette up and down to fully resuspend the pellet in the lysis buffer.
Incubate at room temperature for 7 minutes.







Warning



RBC lysis buffers often contain sodium azide and other toxic components. Avoid skin contact and inhalation. Dispose of lysis waste in accordance with institutional chemical safety rules.



After 7 minutes, top up each tube to 10 mL with FACS buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes (4 °C recommended; standard braking).

title: Mouse Liver Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 6 – Final wash and resuspension

Prepare several layers of paper towel near your waste container.
Discard supernatant from each tube by careful pouring and dab the opening on paper towels to remove residual liquid.
Loosen each pellet in the remaining dead volume by brief vortexing or gentle flicking.
Resuspend each pellet in 5 mL FACS buffer (or another desired final volume) to obtain the final single-cell suspension.
Proceed immediately to:

Cell counting and viability assessment.
Flow cytometry staining and/or FACS sorting.
Sample freezing (e.g. in FBS + 10% DMSO) if required.
Downstream single-cell workflows (e.g. scRNA-seq, scTCR-seq) with appropriate QC.








Tip



For single-cell sequencing applications, minimise the time from tissue harvest to final resuspension, keep samples on ice whenever possible after digestion, and consider additional debris/dead cell removal steps if yields permit.

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-SPL-DIS-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-20

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 1 – Collection and preparation

Euthanise the mouse by an approved method.

Expose the spleen by opening the abdominal cavity.

Excise the spleen and place it into a petri dish containing cold PBS or FACS/MACS Buffer.

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 2 – Mechanical dissociation

Place a 70 μm cell strainer over a 50 mL Falcon tube.

Transfer the spleen onto the strainer.

Using the back of a 5 mL syringe plunger, gently mash the spleen through the mesh until a homogenous suspension is obtained.

Rinse the strainer with FACS/MACS Buffer and top the tube up to 50 mL.







Tip



Use gentle, consistent pressure — avoid grinding, which reduces viability.

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 3 – Wash and centrifugation

Centrifuge the 50 mL tube at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.

Carefully pour off the supernatant.

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 4 – RBC lysis

Add 1 mL HybriMax RBC Lysis Buffer (or equivalent) per spleen to the pellet.

Gently resuspend the pellet by pipetting or flicking.

Incubate for 5 minutes at room temperature.

Top up to 50 mL with FACS/MACS Buffer.







Warning



Over-lysis (>5 minutes) can reduce leukocyte viability and alter scatter profiles.

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 5 – Filtration and final wash

Filter the suspension through a fresh 70 μm strainer into a clean tube.

Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.

Carefully discard supernatant.

Resuspend the pellet in 5 mL FACS/MACS Buffer (or a volume appropriate for your downstream assay).

title: Mouse Spleen Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 6 – Downstream handling
Proceed immediately to:

Flow cytometry staining

FACS sorting

Cryopreservation

Functional assays

Keep cells on ice until use.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-TMR-DIG-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-20

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 1 – Tumour excision and preparation

Euthanise the mouse using an approved method.
Expose the tumour and excise it with sterile scissors and forceps.
Remove fat, necrotic outer layers, and connective tissue using dissection scissors.
Rinse tumour briefly in cold PBS to remove blood and debris.
Transfer to a 10 cm petri dish containing cold PBS or FACS/MACS Buffer.







Tip



Remove necrotic regions; they clog strainers and reduce cell viability.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 2 – Mincing

On a sterile petri dish, mince tumour tissue into very small pieces using scalpels or scissors.

Aim for 1–2 mm fragments for optimal enzyme penetration.

Transfer minced tissue into a 50 mL Falcon tube containing 5 mL Tumour Digestion Buffer (BUF-TMR-DIG-v1.0).

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 3 – Enzymatic digestion

Place tubes on a 37 °C benchtop shaker at 250 rpm.
Incubate for 30–45 minutes, depending on tumour density.
Every 10–15 minutes, remove the tube and gently shake or invert to encourage even digestion.







Warning



Over-digestion (>45 min) can reduce viability, especially in lymphocytes and myeloid cells.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 4 – Mechanical dissociation

Add FACS/MACS Buffer to bring total volume to 20–25 mL.
Pour the digested tumour onto a 70 μm strainer placed over a 10 cm petri dish.
Using the back of a 5 mL syringe plunger, mash the tissue thoroughly through the strainer.

Rinse the strainer with additional cold FACS/MACS Buffer until no visible tissue remains.
Transfer the filtrate back into a clean 50 mL tube.
Top up to 50 mL with cold FACS/MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Carefully discard the supernatant.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 5 – RBC lysis (if required)

If the suspension appears red or contains substantial blood, add 1 mL 1× RBC Lysis Buffer (HybriMax or equivalent).
Mix gently and incubate for 3–5 minutes at room temperature.
Immediately top up to 50 mL with cold FACS/MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Discard supernatant.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 6 – Final wash and filtration

Loosen the pellet by gentle flicking.
Resuspend in 5–10 mL FACS/MACS Buffer.
Filter again through a fresh 70 μm strainer to remove remaining debris and aggregates.
Keep the final cell suspension on ice for downstream applications.

title: Mouse Tumour Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 7 – Downstream applications
Proceed to:

Flow cytometry / TIL profiling

FACS sorting

Tumour microenvironment analyses

Cryopreservation of tumour-derived cell subsets

Single-cell RNA-seq / TCR-seq workflows

title: 4D-Nucleofector CRISPR–Cas9 RNP Delivery to T and NK Cells
text:
Protocol ID: GEN-LYMPH-NUC-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-21

title: 4D-Nucleofector CRISPR–Cas9 RNP Delivery to T and NK Cells
text:
Step 1 – Cell-type–specific lookup
Use the table below to select the appropriate buffer, 4D-Nucleofector program, and starting RNP load for each cell type. All reactions use 20 µL total nucleofection volume in 20 µL Nucleocuvette™ strips.

1.1 Cell-type–specific nucleofection settings

²If both P3 and P4 have been tested for mouse NK, use the solution that gave the best balance of viability and editing in your prior experiments.






Note



This unified protocol describes a common workflow. Cell-type–specific pre-activation (e.g. NK priming, T-cell stimulation) and culture conditions should be followed according to the relevant cell culture SOPs and are not exhaustively detailed here.

title: 4D-Nucleofector CRISPR–Cas9 RNP Delivery to T and NK Cells
section: Step 2 – gRNA duplex and RNP preparation
text:
Step 2 – gRNA duplex and RNP preparation
This section assumes use of crRNA + tracrRNA duplexes and recombinant Cas9 protein.

2.1 crRNA:tracrRNA duplexing

Thaw crRNA and tracrRNA aliquots on ice.

Mix crRNA and tracrRNA at equimolar concentrations (e.g. each at 100 µM) to generate a duplex:

Example: 5 µL crRNA (100 µM) + 5 µL tracrRNA (100 µM) → 10 µL duplex at 100 µM.

Incubate at 95 °C for 5 min, then allow to cool to room temperature (bench-top) for at least 10 min, or follow vendor instructions.
Store duplexed gRNA on ice during RNP preparation.



2.2 RNP assembly

Thaw Cas9 protein aliquots on ice.

For each nucleofection reaction, prepare RNP mix in a low-bind tube:

Example per reaction (starting point, adjust using Table 1):

1.5 µL gRNA duplex (100 µM) → 150 pmol gRNA

3.0 µL Cas9 (20 µM) → 60 pmol Cas9

Optional: add nuclease-free water to increase handling volume, if needed.


Gently mix by pipetting; avoid bubbles.

Incubate the RNP mix at 37 °C for 15 min.

After incubation, keep RNP at room temperature or on ice and use within 1–2 hours for nucleofection.







Warning



Do not repeatedly freeze–thaw Cas9 or gRNA aliquots. Prepare small working aliquots and discard thawed leftovers at the end of the day to preserve activity.

title: 4D-Nucleofector CRISPR–Cas9 RNP Delivery to T and NK Cells
text:
Step 3 – Cell preparation
The steps below describe the unified handling for all T and NK cell types. Follow cell-type–specific culture SOPs for prior expansion and activation.

3.1 Harvesting cells

Harvest cells from culture flasks or plates at the desired time point (e.g. 2–3 days post activation for T cells; 3 days post priming for NK).

For suspension cultures (mouse NK, NK-92, activated T cells): gently resuspend by pipetting up and down.

For mixed cultures (e.g. mouse spleen-derived T or NK), process according to the relevant isolation SOP (e.g. magnetic separation) before nucleofection.



3.2 Washing and counting

Transfer cells to 15 mL conical tubes.

Centrifuge at 300–400 g for 5 min at room temperature.

Carefully aspirate supernatant.

Resuspend the pellet in 10 mL DPBS or PBS and mix gently.

Centrifuge again under the same conditions.

Aspirate the supernatant completely.

Take an aliquot and count cells (e.g. trypan blue exclusion).

Calculate total cell number and plan 0.5–1.0 × 10⁶ cells per nucleofection reaction.







Warning



Residual serum or culture medium in the pellet will reduce nucleofection efficiency and viability. After the final wash, remove supernatant carefully and completely before adding nucleofector solution.

title: 4D-Nucleofector CRISPR–Cas9 RNP Delivery to T and NK Cells
section: Step 4 – Resuspension in nucleofector solution and mixing with RNP
text:
Step 4 – Resuspension in nucleofector solution and mixing with RNP

4.1 Preparation of nucleofector cell suspension

Pre-equilibrate nucleofector solutions (P3, P4, SE) to room temperature as recommended by the manufacturer.

For each cell type, prepare enough nucleofector solution for all planned reactions, following the kit instructions (e.g. supplementing solution with additive as required).

Resuspend washed cells in the appropriate nucleofector solution at a concentration of:

5 × 10⁷ cells/mL for 1.0 × 10⁶ cells in 20 µL

2.5 × 10⁷ cells/mL for 0.5 × 10⁶ cells in 20 µL

Gently mix and keep at room temperature. Avoid leaving cells in nucleofector solution for longer than 15–20 min before pulsing.



4.2 Mixing cells with RNP
For each reaction:

Aliquot the appropriate volume of RNP mix into a fresh low-bind tube or directly into the well/strip position (e.g. 4.5 µL per reaction).

Add nucleofector cell suspension to reach a total volume of 20 µL per reaction:

Example: 4.5 µL RNP + 15.5 µL cell suspension.


Gently pipette up and down to mix; avoid introducing air bubbles.

Immediately proceed to loading the Nucleocuvette™.

title: 4D-Nucleofector CRISPR–Cas9 RNP Delivery to T and NK Cells
section: Step 5 – Loading Nucleocuvette™ and running the 4D program
text:
Step 5 – Loading Nucleocuvette™ and running the 4D program

5.1 Loading Nucleocuvette™ strips

Place the 20 µL Nucleocuvette™ strip into its holder.

Carefully pipette 20 µL of the RNP–cell mix into each well, aiming the pipette tip to the side of the well to minimise bubbles.

Visually inspect each well for uniform filling and absence of air pockets.

Insert the holder into the 4D-Nucleofector X unit.



5.2 Selecting and running programs

On the 4D-Nucleofector control unit, select the nucleofection program corresponding to the cell type (see lookup table in Step 1).

Confirm that the selected program and kit (P3, P4, SE) match the cells in the strip.

Start the nucleofection run.

When complete, remove the Nucleocuvette™ strip promptly and place it in a biosafety cabinet.







Note



If running multiple cell types in parallel, clearly separate strips by cell type and program to avoid mismatches. Only one program can be used per strip/run.

title: 4D-Nucleofector CRISPR–Cas9 RNP Delivery to T and NK Cells
text:
Step 6 – Immediate post-nucleofection rescue

6.1 Addition of rescue medium in cuvette

Immediately after nucleofection, add 60–100 µL of pre-warmed culture medium directly into each Nucleocuvette™ well:

Use the appropriate base medium (e.g. T-cell medium, NK medium, or NK-92 medium).

Cytokines may be omitted from this initial rescue step if preferred (see cell-type notes below).

Gently pipette up and down once to mix, without generating bubbles.

Place the Nucleocuvette™ strip into a 37 °C incubator (inside a sterile container) or keep at 37 °C in the biosafety cabinet if feasible.
Allow cells to recover in the cuvette for 10–25 min.



6.2 Transfer to culture plates

After the recovery period, gently resuspend each Nucleocuvette™ well by pipetting up and down.

Transfer the entire volume (typically 80–120 µL) into the corresponding well of a pre-warmed 96- or 48-well plate or into a culture tube containing:

Final volume: 200–1000 µL per well/tube.

Appropriate cytokine supplementation, for example:

Naïve mouse T: IL-7 ± low IL-2.

Activated T (mouse/human): IL-2 ± IL-7.

Mouse NK: IL-15 + IL-2 as per NK culture SOP.

NK-92: NK-92 medium ± IL-2 as per NK-92 culture SOP.


Adjust final cell density to 0.5–1.0 × 10⁶ cells/mL for standard culture.

Incubate plates at 37 °C, 5% CO₂.







Warning



Do not leave nucleofected cells in undiluted nucleofector buffer longer than necessary. Rescue medium should be added within minutes after the pulse and cells should be transferred to standard culture conditions within 30–40 min.

title: 4D-Nucleofector CRISPR–Cas9 RNP Delivery to T and NK Cells
text:
Step 7 – Recommended timelines for analysis
Although the exact timepoint will depend on the target locus and downstream readouts, the following windows are commonly used:

Mouse NK cells: assess viability and KO efficiency at day 3 and day 7.

Mouse T cells (naïve/activated): assess between day 3–6, with extended phenotyping up to day 10–15 when needed.

Human T cells (activated): assess at day 3–5 post nucleofection.

NK-92: assess between day 3–5 post nucleofection.

Choice of timepoint should balance maximal editing efficiency with sufficient recovery and expansion.

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
text:
Protocol ID: GEN-FLOW-STD-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-21

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
section: Step 1 – Plate setup and FACS buffer
text:
Step 1 – Plate setup and FACS buffer

Prepare FACS buffer (BUF-GEN-FACS-BUF-001):

PBS, 1×

2 % FCS (heat-inactivated)

2 mM EDTA


Prepare single-cell suspensions of the desired samples.
Count cells and adjust concentration so that you can plate up to 5 × 10⁵ cells per well of a 96-well U-bottom or V-bottom plate.
Aliquot cells into the plate (typically 5 × 10⁵ cells per well or less).
Keep plates on ice (or at 4 °C) until staining begins.

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
section: Step 2 – Fc block and live/dead staining
text:
Step 2 – Fc block and live/dead staining

Prepare a staining mix in FACS buffer containing Fc block and live/dead dye:

Fc block: 1:200 dilution.

Live/dead dye: 1:100 dilution.

Final volume: 50 µL per well.

Add 50 µL of this Fc block + live/dead mix to each well containing cells.
Gently tap or briefly pulse-centrifuge the plate if needed to ensure mixing.
Incubate on ice (or at 4 °C) for the time recommended by the live/dead reagent manufacturer (typically 15–20 min), protected from light.
Centrifuge the plate at 1000 g for 2 min.
Quickly flick off the supernatant into a suitable waste container.







Warning



Live/dead dyes are light-sensitive and can be toxic at high concentrations or with prolonged incubation. Avoid direct light and adhere to the manufacturer’s recommended dilution and incubation times.

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
text:
Step 3 – Surface staining

Prepare a surface staining master mix in FACS buffer with all desired surface antibodies:

Total volume: 50 µL per well.
Antibody dilutions according to titration data (commonly 1:50–1:200).

Resuspend cell pellets in 50 µL surface stain master mix per well.
Incubate the plate on ice for 30 min, protected from light.
After incubation, top up each well to 200 µL with FACS buffer.
Centrifuge the plate at 400 g for 2 min.
Flick off the supernatant.
Wash the cells by adding 200 µL FACS buffer to each well, gently resuspending the pellet, and centrifuging again at 400 g for 2 min.
Flick off the supernatant.


3.1 If only surface staining is required

Resuspend each pellet in 100–200 µL of 4 % PFA solution (or appropriate fixative) in PBS.
Store plates at 4 °C, protected from light, until acquisition.

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
section: Step 4 – Fixation and permeabilization for intracellular or intranuclear staining
text:
Step 4 – Fixation and permeabilization for intracellular or intranuclear staining
This step assumes the use of:

BD intracellular staining kit (e.g. Cytofix/Cytoperm) for cytoplasmic targets, or

eBioscience FOXP3 or equivalent intranuclear staining kit for transcription factors.

Always consult the kit manuals; the steps below mirror the original SOP structure.

4.1 Initial fix/perm

Add 100 µL of BD fix/perm solution (e.g. Cytofix/Cytoperm) or eBioscience FOXP3 fix/perm solution (typically 1:4 concentrate with 3:4 diluent) to each well.
Incubate for 20 min on ice, protected from light.
Top up each well to 200 µL with 1× PermWash (diluted in water, according to the kit instructions).
Centrifuge the plate and flick off the supernatant.
Resuspend each pellet in 200 µL 1× PermWash.
Centrifuge the plate and flick off the supernatant.



4.2 Pause point (optional, overnight)

Resuspend each pellet in 200 µL FACS buffer.
Seal and label the plate clearly.
Store at 4 °C overnight, protected from light.







Note



An overnight pause at this stage can be convenient for scheduling, but confirm that your antigen of interest and fluorochromes are stable under these conditions.




4.3 Re-permeabilization before intranuclear staining (if using FOXP3 kit)

The following day, centrifuge the plate at 1000 g for 2 min and flick off the supernatant.
Resuspend pellets in 200 µL 1× PermWash (FOXP3 kit).
Incubate for 30 min on ice, protected from light.
Centrifuge and flick off the supernatant.

title: Standard Flow Cytometry Staining (Surface, Intracellular, Intranuclear)
text:
Step 5 – Intracellular or intranuclear staining

Prepare an intracellular or intranuclear staining master mix in the appropriate PermWash (kit-specific):

Total volume: 50 µL per well.
Antibody dilutions according to titration data (typically 1:50–1:200).

Resuspend each pellet in 50 µL of the master mix.
Incubate on ice for 30 min, protected from light.
Top up each well to 200 µL with PermWash.
Centrifuge and flick off the supernatant.
Wash once more with 200 µL PermWash and centrifuge.
Flick off the supernatant.
Resuspend each pellet in 100–200 µL of 4 % PFA solution (or other appropriate fixative) in PBS.
Store plates at 4 °C, protected from light, until acquisition.

title: ACK Red Blood Cell Lysis Buffer
section: Preparation of 1 L ACK lysis buffer
text:
Preparation of 1 L ACK lysis buffer

Add the following to a 1 L glass bottle or beaker:

8.02 g NH₄Cl (150 mM)

1.00 g KHCO₃ (10 mM)

0.037 g Na₂EDTA (0.1 mM)

Add ~800 mL sterile distilled water.
Stir or gently swirl until fully dissolved.
Adjust the final volume to 1 L with sterile distilled water.
Filter-sterilize using a 0.22 µm PES or PVDF filter.
Aliquot if desired.


pH adjustment

Typically no pH adjustment is required; the solution should be at pH ~7.2–7.4.

If necessary, adjust minimally with sterile HCl or NaOH.

text:
Protocol ID: BUF-FACS-v1.0
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-20

Purpose
This buffer is used for washing and resuspending cells during flow cytometry staining, FACS sorting, and MACS-based enrichment. It helps maintain cell viability, prevents clumping, and minimises nonspecific binding.


Linked protocols
This buffer is used in:

Mouse Liver Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension – LIV-001 (v1.0)

Preparation

Storage and stability

Store at 4 °C, protected from light if possible.
Recommended to use within 4–6 weeks, or according to internal lab validation and microbial QC.
Before use, invert gently to resuspend any settled components.
Avoid repeated temperature cycling; if frequent bench use is expected, consider preparing smaller working aliquots.

title: 33% Percoll Solution
text:
Protocol ID: BUF-PERC-33-v1.0
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-20

Purpose
This buffer is used as a 33% Percoll solution for density-based enrichment of leukocytes from digested liver. It separates hepatocytes (floating) from leukocyte- and erythrocyte-enriched pellets during centrifugation.


Linked protocols
This buffer is used in:

Mouse Liver Dissociation to Single-Cell Suspension – LIV-001 (v1.0)



Composition (per 10 mL 33% Percoll)
Based on the original SOP:










Component
Stock
Volume for 10 mL
Approx. final composition
Notes




Percoll (sterile)
100%
3.33 mL
33% (v/v)
Undiluted stock


PBS 1×
—
6.29 mL
—
Isotonic medium


PBS 10×
10×
370.37 µL
Adjusts osmolarity
Added last





Preparation

Equilibrate Percoll stock to room temperature before preparation.
For each 10 mL of 33% Percoll:

In a sterile 15 mL or 50 mL tube, add 3.33 mL Percoll (sterile).
Add 6.29 mL PBS 1×.
Add 370.37 µL PBS 10×.
Mix gently by inversion until homogeneous.

If preparing multiple aliquots (e.g. 10 mL per liver), scale volumes accordingly.
Aliquot 10 mL per labeled 15 mL tube for each liver sample.
Label tubes with:

“33% Percoll”
Date of preparation
Version (BUF-PERC-33-v1.0)








Note



Maintain sterility by preparing the solution in a biosafety cabinet or sterile environment if it will contact viable cells used for culture or sensitive downstream applications.




Storage and stability

Working 33% Percoll solution is generally prepared fresh on the day of use.
Short-term storage (same day) at room temperature is acceptable.
Do not freeze 33% Percoll; discard any unused working solution at the end of the day.
Stock Percoll (100%) should be stored according to manufacturer’s instructions (typically at room temperature), protected from contamination.

title: Liver Digestion Buffer
text:
Protocol ID: BUF-LIV-DIG-v1.0
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-20

title: Liver Digestion Buffer
text:
A. Prepare “Liver Digestion Stock (no DNase)”
This stock is DMEM + Collagenase D, without DNase. It is frozen in aliquots for convenient use.

Thaw Collagenase D stock (100 mg/mL) on ice or at 4 °C.
In a sterile tube, prepare the digestion stock for the desired number of aliquots, for example:

For each 5 mL stock aliquot:

Add ~4 mL DMEM (incomplete).
Add 10 µL Collagenase D stock (100 mg/mL).
Mix gently by inversion (avoid foaming).
Bring volume to 5 mL with DMEM (incomplete).


Aliquot the digestion stock into sterile tubes (e.g. 3–5 mL per aliquot, depending on typical experimental usage).
Label aliquots clearly with:

“Liver Digestion Stock (no DNase)”
Concentration
Date
Version (BUF-LIV-DIG-v1.0)

Freeze aliquots at −20 °C.

title: Liver Digestion Buffer
section: B. Prepare final working Liver Digestion Buffer (day of use)
text:
B. Prepare final working Liver Digestion Buffer (day of use)

Remove the required number of Liver Digestion Stock (no DNase) aliquots from −20 °C and thaw at room temperature or 4 °C.
For each 5 mL of final working buffer needed:

Ensure the thawed stock is well mixed (gentle inversion).
Add 1 µL of DNase I stock (10 mg/mL) to 5 mL digestion stock.
Mix gently by inversion.

Pre-warm the final working buffer to 37 °C before use (e.g. by placing tubes in a 37 °C water bath or incubator).
If desired, pre-aliquot 3 mL of the final working buffer into pre-labeled 50 mL liver collection tubes, and retain additional buffer in a separate tube for perfusion.







Tip



To minimise variability, prepare all working-buffer aliquots for a given experiment at the same time using the same DNase stock and keep them at 37 °C only for as long as required during the digestion step.

title: Liver Digestion Buffer
text:
Liver Digestion Stock (no DNase)

Composition: DMEM (incomplete) + Collagenase D at 1 mg/mL final (when diluted as described).
Storage:

Store aliquots at −20 °C.
Avoid repeated freeze–thaw cycles (use single-use aliquots where possible).

Stability:

Recommended to use within 3–6 months of preparation, or according to internal lab validation.

Before use:

Thaw at room temperature or 4 °C.
Mix gently to ensure homogeneity.

title: Liver Digestion Buffer
section: Final working Liver Digestion Buffer (with DNase)
text:
Final working Liver Digestion Buffer (with DNase)

Prepared from thawed Liver Digestion Stock (no DNase) + DNase I.
Use on the same day as preparation.
Keep at 37 °C only during active digestion steps; otherwise, keep at room temperature for short periods.
Do not refreeze working buffer once DNase has been added; discard any unused working buffer at the end of the day.

title: Liver Digestion Buffer
text:
Stock reagents

Collagenase D stock (100 mg/mL)

Store as recommended by the manufacturer (typically −20 °C in aliquots).

Avoid repeated freeze–thaw cycles.

DNase I stock (10 mg/mL)

Store according to manufacturer’s instructions (often −20 °C).

Avoid repeated freeze–thaw cycles.

DMEM (incomplete)

Store at 4 °C, protected from light.

Respect manufacturer’s expiry date.








Note



If the lab validates alternative storage conditions (e.g. short-term storage of working buffer at 4 °C), document the conditions and update the version number and description accordingly.

title: CellTrace Violet (CTV) Staining of Lymphocytes
text:
Protocol ID: GEN-CTV-STAIN-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-21

title: CellTrace Violet (CTV) Staining of Lymphocytes
text:
Step 1 – Cell preparation and resting

If using frozen PBMCs:

Thaw vials rapidly in a 37 °C water bath until a small ice crystal remains.
Immediately transfer the cell suspension into a tube containing pre-warmed R10 medium (BUF-GEN-R10-MED-001) and mix gently.
Centrifuge at ~400–500 g for 5 min at room temperature.
Discard the supernatant and resuspend cells in fresh R10.

Optionally add DNase I (e.g. 10 µL/mL of an appropriate stock) to reduce clumping during the initial rest period.
Incubate cells at 37 °C, 5 % CO₂ for ~1 hour to recover from thawing and improve viability.
Count cells and assess viability using trypan blue or an equivalent method.
Adjust the cell concentration as needed to allow resuspension at 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL in PBS in the next step.

title: CellTrace Violet (CTV) Staining of Lymphocytes
section: Step 2 – Preparation of CellTrace Violet stock
text:
Step 2 – Preparation of CellTrace Violet stock

Reconstitute one vial of CellTrace Violet in 20 µL DMSO in a biosafety cabinet.
Mix gently by pipetting; avoid foaming or vortexing.
Aliquot the stock if desired and store according to the manufacturer’s recommendations (typically −20 °C, protected from light).







Note



Prepare CTV stock fresh on the day of use or use single-use aliquots to avoid repeated freeze–thaw cycles.

title: CellTrace Violet (CTV) Staining of Lymphocytes
text:
Step 3 – CTV staining

Pellet cells and resuspend in PBS without FCS at 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL.
For each mL of cell suspension, add 0.2–0.5 µL of the CTV stock solution (based on prior titration).
Immediately mix by gentle pipetting or brief low-speed vortexing to ensure even distribution of the dye.
Incubate cells for 20 min at room temperature, protected from light.
During incubation, gently invert or tap the tube once or twice to maintain a uniform suspension.







Warning



Do not stain cells in R10 or other serum-containing media. Proteins in the medium will quench the dye and lead to weak or inconsistent staining.

title: CellTrace Violet (CTV) Staining of Lymphocytes
text:
Step 4 – Quenching and washing

After 20 min, add 5× the original staining volume of pre-warmed R10 (e.g. add 5 mL R10 to 1 mL stained cells) to quench unbound dye.
Incubate for 5 min at room temperature, protected from light.
Centrifuge at ~400–500 g for 5 min (or ~1200 rpm in a standard cell-culture centrifuge, if this corresponds to the correct g-force).
Discard the supernatant carefully.
Optional extended wash (recommended for higher CTV concentrations or sensitive cell types):

Resuspend cells in up to 10 mL R10.

Centrifuge again at ~400–500 g for 5 min.

Discard the supernatant.

Repeat once more if residual dye is a concern.

title: CellTrace Violet (CTV) Staining of Lymphocytes
text:
Step 5 – Final resuspension and equilibration

Resuspend cells in R10 (BUF-GEN-R10-MED-001) at the desired concentration for stimulation or culture (commonly 0.5–2 × 10⁶ cells/mL).
Incubate for at least 10 min at 37 °C, 5 % CO₂ to allow stabilization of dye distribution within the cells.
Proceed with downstream steps such as:

Addition of stimuli for proliferation assays.
Plating for co-culture experiments.
Subsequent staining for surface markers prior to acquisition.

title: Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-LIV-NLC-ISO-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-21

title: Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
text:
Step 1 – Preparation and setup

Pre-cool PBS on ice.
Label 50 mL conical tubes and gentleMACS C-tubes (or equivalent) for each liver.
For each liver, prepare:

5 mL ice-cold PBS in a 50 mL tube for transport.

Prepare the following buffers (see separate buffer protocols):

Liver digestion buffer (BUF-MUS-LIV-DIG-001; collagenase IV + DNase I in PBS).
37 % Percoll working solution (BUF-GEN-PERC-37PCT-001).
ACK lysis buffer (BUF-GEN-ACK-LYSIS-001).
FACS buffer (BUF-GEN-FACS-BUF-001), if needed for downstream steps.

Set a refrigerated benchtop centrifuge to 4 °C.
Ensure access to a gentleMACS instrument with an appropriate liver dissociation program.

title: Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
section: Step 2 – Mouse sacrifice and liver perfusion
text:
Step 2 – Mouse sacrifice and liver perfusion

Sacrifice mice according to institutional and ethical guidelines (e.g. CO₂ asphyxiation followed by cervical dislocation, as approved).
Place the mouse in a supine position on a suitable surface.
Open the abdominal cavity to expose the liver and major vessels.
Perfuse the liver with ice-cold PBS via one of the following routes:

Inferior vena cava

Portal vein

Directly via the heart

Gently insert a needle into the chosen vessel and perfuse with PBS until the liver visibly blanches (typically ~5–10 mL per mouse).







Note



Efficient perfusion reduces blood content and improves the quality of density separation and downstream staining.



After perfusion, proceed immediately to liver collection.

title: Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
text:
Step 3 – Liver collection and mincing

Excise the perfused liver using sterile, autoclaved instruments.
Transfer the liver into the pre-labelled 50 mL tube containing 5 mL ice-cold PBS.
Keep the tube on ice.
Transfer the liver to a sterile Petri dish placed on ice.
Using autoclaved scissors or scalpels, mince the liver into small pieces (~2–3 mm) to facilitate enzymatic digestion.
Transfer the minced liver pieces into a gentleMACS C-tube.

title: Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
section: Step 4 – Enzymatic digestion and gentleMACS processing
text:
Step 4 – Enzymatic digestion and gentleMACS processing

For each liver C-tube, add:

2 mL of 2× liver digestion buffer (BUF-MUS-LIV-DIG-001).

2 mL PBS.
Total volume: 4 mL.

Close the C-tube tightly and ensure the cap is well seated.







Warning



Make sure the gentleMACS C-tube is firmly closed and correctly positioned. Leaks during the run can lead to sample loss and contamination of the instrument.



Place the tube on the gentleMACS and run an appropriate liver dissociation program according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
Immediately after mechanical dissociation, incubate the tube at 37 °C so that the total enzymatic digestion time is approximately 17 min (including any on-instrument warm steps, if applicable).
If compatible with the program, gently invert the tube once or twice during incubation to improve digestion.







Note



The specific gentleMACS program used may vary. Choose a liver-optimized program that preserves lymphocyte viability.

title: Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
section: Step 5 – Removal of hepatocytes and washing
text:
Step 5 – Removal of hepatocytes and washing

After digestion, transfer the liver cell suspension from the C-tube into a 50 mL conical tube.
Rinse the C-tube with PBS and add the rinse to the same 50 mL tube to maximize yield.
Bring the volume up to 50 mL with ice-cold PBS.
Centrifuge at 50 g for 2 min at 4 °C to sediment hepatocytes.
Carefully transfer the supernatant (containing lymphocytes and smaller cells) to a fresh pre-cooled 50 mL tube without disturbing the hepatocyte pellet.
Adjust the volume to 50 mL with ice-cold PBS.
Centrifuge at 1600 rpm (approximately 547 g) for 10 min at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and keep the cell pellet on ice.

title: Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
section: Step 6 – 37 % Percoll enrichment of liver-associated lymphocytes
text:
Step 6 – 37 % Percoll enrichment of liver-associated lymphocytes

Gently resuspend the cell pellet in 10 mL of 37 % Percoll (BUF-GEN-PERC-37PCT-001) prepared in PBS.
Mix gently by pipetting until the pellet is fully resuspended.
Centrifuge at 800 g for 20 min at 4 °C, using:

Moderate acceleration (e.g. acc 7).

Minimal brake (e.g. br 1) to avoid disturbing the gradient.








Warning



Avoid high brake settings during Percoll centrifugation. Abrupt braking can disrupt the gradient and reduce lymphocyte enrichment.



After centrifugation, carefully discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the enriched lymphocyte pellet in 20–30 mL ice-cold PBS.
Centrifuge at 1600 rpm (~547 g) for 10 min at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and keep the pellet on ice.

title: Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
section: Step 7 – Red blood cell lysis and filtration
text:
Step 7 – Red blood cell lysis and filtration

Gently resuspend the cell pellet in 2 mL ACK lysis buffer (BUF-GEN-ACK-LYSIS-001) at room temperature.
Incubate for 2 min at room temperature, gently inverting once.







Warning



Do not exceed 2–3 min in ACK buffer. Prolonged exposure can damage lymphocytes and reduce viability.



Quench the lysis by adding 20 mL ice-cold PBS.
Pass the suspension through a 70 µm cell strainer into a fresh 50 mL tube kept on ice.
Rinse the strainer with an additional 5–10 mL PBS if needed to recover remaining cells.
Centrifuge at 1500 rpm (~500–550 g) for 10 min at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and keep the pellet on ice.

title: Isolation of Liver-Associated Lymphocytes (LALs) Including NLCs from Mouse Liver
text:
Step 8 – Final wash and resuspension

Resuspend the cell pellet in 10–20 mL ice-cold PBS (depending on pellet size).
Centrifuge at 1500 rpm (~500–550 g) for 5–10 min at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the final cell pellet in an appropriate volume of:

PBS or FACS buffer (BUF-GEN-FACS-BUF-001) for immediate staining, or

Culture medium (e.g. R10 or NK cell medium) for downstream functional assays.

Count cells and assess viability (e.g. trypan blue) as required.
Proceed with downstream applications (e.g. flow cytometry, sorting, or culture of NLCs).

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-LNG-DIG-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-20

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 1 – Lung collection

Euthanise the mouse using an approved method.
Open the thoracic cavity to expose the lungs.
(Optional but recommended) Perfuse via the right ventricle with cold PBS until lungs visibly blanch, reducing RBC content.
Excise the entire lung block and place it in a 10 cm petri dish containing cold PBS or FACS/MACS Buffer.







Tip



Perfusion markedly improves final leukocyte purity and reduces RBC lysis requirements.

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 2 – Tissue mincing

Blot the lungs briefly on sterile tissue to remove excess fluid.
Transfer to a fresh 10 cm dish and mince thoroughly using scissors or scalpels until small fragments are obtained.
Transfer the minced lung into a 50 mL Falcon tube containing 5 mL Lung Digestion Buffer (see buffer protocol BUF-LNG-DIG-v1.0).

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 3 – Enzymatic digestion

Place tubes on a 37 °C benchtop shaker at 250 rpm.
Incubate for 30–35 minutes.







Warning



Over-digestion can decrease viability and negatively impact epithelial and myeloid populations.

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 4 – Mechanical dissociation

After digestion, add FACS/MACS Buffer to bring total volume to 25 mL.
Pour the suspension onto a 70 μm cell strainer placed on a 10 cm dish.
Mechanically mash the digested lung through the mesh using the back of a 5 mL syringe plunger.
Rinse the strainer with cold FACS/MACS Buffer until no visible tissue remains.
Transfer the filtered cell suspension back into a 50 mL tube.
Top up to 50 mL with cold FACS/MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Carefully discard the supernatant.

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 5 – RBC removal (if required)
Lung digests vary in RBC content. If erythrocytes are visible:

Add 1 mL 1× RBC Lysis Buffer (e.g. HybriMax) per lung.

Mix gently and incubate for 3–5 minutes at room temperature.
Immediately top up to 50 mL with cold FACS/MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Discard supernatant.







Note



If the lung was perfused effectively, this step may not be needed.

title: Mouse Lung Digestion to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 6 – Final wash and resuspension

Loosen pellet by gentle flicking or brief vortexing.
Resuspend in 5 mL FACS/MACS Buffer (or other desired volume).
Filter again through a fresh 70 μm strainer if clumping is observed.
Keep the suspension on ice until staining, sorting, or single-cell workflows.

title: Mouse Bone Marrow Isolation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-BM-ISO-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-20

title: Mouse Bone Marrow Isolation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 1 – Bone collection

Euthanise the mouse using an approved method.
Spray the hind limbs with 70% ethanol and transfer the carcass to a sterile working area (e.g. Class II biosafety cabinet, if available).
Dissect out femurs and tibias (or other long bones as required) using scissors and forceps.
Remove all excess muscle and connective tissue from the bones.
Place cleaned bones in a 50 mL tube or petri dish containing cold FACS/MACS Buffer or PBS and keep on ice.







Tip



You can pool bones from multiple mice in a single tube for batch processing, but keep track of how many bones per tube in your notebook.

title: Mouse Bone Marrow Isolation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 2 – Flushing the bone marrow

In a petri dish or on a sterile surface, cut or snap off the epiphyses (ends) of each bone with sterile scissors to expose the marrow cavity.
Fill a 10 mL syringe fitted with an appropriate gauge needle (e.g. 25 G) with cold FACS/MACS Buffer or PBS.
Position the needle into one end of the bone and flush the marrow into a petri dish or 50 mL tube:

Use ~1–3 mL buffer per bone, depending on size.

Repeat flushing from both ends if necessary until the bone appears pale and empty.
Gently triturate the flushed marrow with a 5–10 mL pipette or by drawing up and down with the syringe (without needle) to break up clumps.







Warning



Avoid vigorous pipetting that shears cells; use gentle, repeated strokes to obtain a single-cell suspension.

title: Mouse Bone Marrow Isolation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 3 – Filtration and initial wash

Place a 70 μm cell strainer onto a 50 mL Falcon tube.
Pour the marrow suspension through the strainer to remove bone fragments and debris.
Rinse the petri dish and strainer with additional cold FACS/MACS Buffer to collect remaining cells and top up to 20–30 mL.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Carefully discard the supernatant.

title: Mouse Bone Marrow Isolation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 4 – RBC lysis (if required)

Gently resuspend the bone marrow pellet in 1–2 mL 1× RBC Lysis Buffer (e.g. HybriMax or equivalent), depending on pellet size.
Incubate for 3–5 minutes at room temperature, gently inverting the tube once or twice.







Warning



Do not exceed 5 minutes of RBC lysis; prolonged exposure can reduce leukocyte viability and alter surface marker expression.



After lysis, immediately top up the tube to 20–30 mL with FACS/MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 minutes at 4 °C.
Carefully discard the supernatant.

title: Mouse Bone Marrow Isolation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 5 – Final wash and resuspension

Gently flick or briefly vortex to loosen the pellet.
Resuspend cells in 5–10 mL FACS/MACS Buffer (adjust volume according to desired final concentration and downstream application).
If residual clumping is observed, pass the suspension again through a 70 μm strainer into a fresh tube.
Keep the suspension on ice until counting, staining, or further processing.

title: Mouse Bone Marrow Isolation to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 6 – Downstream applications
Proceed to:

Cell counting and viability assessment.
Flow cytometry staining panels (e.g. hematopoietic profiling).
FACS sorting (e.g. HSCs, progenitors, mature lineages).
Functional assays or in vitro culture as per experimental design.

title: Mouse Blood Processing to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
Protocol ID: MUS-BLD-PRC-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-20

title: Mouse Blood Processing to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 1 – Blood collection

Prepare EDTA-containing microcentrifuge tubes (20–40 μL EDTA per tube) and label one tube per mouse.
Collect blood using an insulin syringe (or other approved method, e.g. retro-orbital, submandibular, cardiac puncture as per ethics approval).
Immediately dispense the blood into the EDTA tube.
Flick the tube gently to mix blood with EDTA and prevent clotting.







Warning



Ensure local ethics approval covers the chosen blood collection method. Handle sharps carefully and discard immediately into an approved sharps container.

title: Mouse Blood Processing to Single-Cell Suspension
section: STEP 2 – Allocate sample volume and initial spin
text:
STEP 2 – Allocate sample volume and initial spin

Transfer a defined volume of well-mixed whole blood (e.g. 100–200 μL, or as required) from the EDTA tube into a new, labelled microcentrifuge tube.

Record the volume used per sample in your lab notebook.

Centrifuge the whole blood at maximum g (bench-top microcentrifuge) for 5 minutes at room temperature or 4 °C.
Carefully remove the serum:

Discard, or
Aliquot and freeze at −20 °C or −80 °C if required for serum analyses.

title: Mouse Blood Processing to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 3 – RBC lysis

Gently resuspend the remaining blood pellet in 1 mL of 1× RBC lysis buffer (e.g. BioLegend / HybriMax 1×).

Transfer the suspension to a 15 mL Falcon tube.
Gently mix by inversion or brief pipetting to ensure complete resuspension.
Incubate for 5 minutes at room temperature.







Warning



Do not exceed the recommended lysis time; prolonged exposure to RBC lysis buffer can damage leukocytes and alter marker expression.

title: Mouse Blood Processing to Single-Cell Suspension
text:
STEP 4 – Wash and final resuspension

After the 5-minute lysis, top up the tube to 10 mL with FACS/MACS Buffer.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 4–5 minutes at 4 °C.
Carefully pour off or aspirate the supernatant.
If substantial red cell contamination remains:

Repeat the RBC lysis step (STEP 3) once more, followed by the wash in STEP 4.

Finally, resuspend the cell pellet in an appropriate volume of FACS/MACS Buffer (e.g. 0.5–1 mL) for:

Flow cytometry staining
Cell counting
Other downstream assays


Keep the cell suspension on ice until staining.

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
text:
Protocol ID: HUM-BLD-PBMC-ISO-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-21

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
section: Step 1 – Tube labelling and blood dilution
text:
Step 1 – Tube labelling and blood dilution

Label 50 mL conical tubes for each blood sample.
For each sample, add whole blood to a 50 mL tube:

Transfer up to 17.5 mL whole blood per 50 mL tube.

Dilute blood 1:2 with R0 medium (RPMI without FCS; BUF-GEN-R0-MED-001):

Add 17.5 mL R0 to 17.5 mL blood (total 35 mL).

If using less than 17.5 mL blood, top up to 35 mL with R0.








Note



Dilution with R0 reduces viscosity, improves layering on Ficoll, and can improve separation quality.

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
section: Step 2 – Ficoll layering and gradient centrifugation
text:
Step 2 – Ficoll layering and gradient centrifugation

In a fresh 50 mL tube, add 10 mL Ficoll (density gradient medium).
Using a 10 mL serological pipette, slowly overlay the 35 mL diluted blood onto the Ficoll:

Hold the Ficoll tube at a gentle angle.
Carefully dispense the diluted blood onto the Ficoll surface, avoiding mixing.
Maximum volume of diluted blood per tube: 35 mL.

Prepare all Ficoll gradients required and ensure they are balanced.
Centrifuge at 450 g (rcf) for 30 min at room temperature with:

Acceleration: 2

Deceleration: 1 (minimal brake)

During centrifugation, prepare 10 mL tubes containing 3 mL R0 (2 tubes per Ficoll gradient) for PBMC collection.

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
section: Step 3 – Harvest of PBMC layer and first wash
text:
Step 3 – Harvest of PBMC layer and first wash

After centrifugation, identify:

Plasma / diluted medium layer on top.
A white, “fluffy” PBMC layer at the plasma/Ficoll interface.
Ficoll layer.
Pellet of erythrocytes and granulocytes at the bottom.

Using a sterile transfer pipette, gently harvest the PBMC layer:

Carefully aspirate the interface and transfer to a 10 mL tube containing 3 mL R0.
Continue until the visible fluffy layer is removed.

For each gradient, distribute the collected PBMCs across two 10 mL tubes (each with 3 mL R0).
Centrifuge the 10 mL tubes at 400 g for 10 min at room temperature:

Acceleration: 9

Deceleration: 9

Carefully remove and discard the supernatant without disturbing the cell pellets.

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
section: Step 4 – Second wash and resuspension in R10
text:
Step 4 – Second wash and resuspension in R10

Resuspend each PBMC pellet in 3 mL R0.
Combine two pellets into one tube and top up to 10 mL R0.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 min at room temperature:

Acceleration: 9

Deceleration: 9

Remove and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 10 mL R10 (complete RPMI with 10 % FCS; BUF-GEN-R10-MED-001).
If multiple gradients were processed for the same sample, combine their PBMC pellets into a single tube in R10.
Centrifuge at 400 g for 5 min at room temperature.
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 1–10 mL R10, depending on pellet size and planned downstream use.

title: Isolation of Human PBMCs from Whole Blood by Ficoll Gradient
text:
Step 5 – Counting and cryopreservation (optional)

Mix the cell suspension gently and take a small aliquot for counting with trypan blue or an equivalent viability dye.
Calculate the total number of viable PBMCs.
For cryopreservation, aim for a final concentration of 10 × 10⁶ cells/mL per cryovial.


5.1 Preparation of 2× freezing medium (BUF-GEN-FREEZE-MIX-001)

Prepare 2× freezing medium by mixing:

7 mL R0

1 mL FCS

2 mL DMSO
(Final: R0 + 10 % FCS + 20 % DMSO; 2× relative to standard 10 % DMSO freezing medium.)

Keep the 2× freezing medium on ice and protected from light.



5.2 Adjust cell concentration and freeze

Adjust PBMCs in R10 to 20 × 10⁶ cells/mL:

If only one cryovial is needed, pellet cells at 200 g for 5 min, remove supernatant, and resuspend so that the cell pellet is in 500 µL R10 (20 × 10⁶ cells/mL).

Add an equal volume of 2× freezing medium (BUF-GEN-FREEZE-MIX-001) to the cells:

Final concentration: 10 × 10⁶ cells/mL in 10 % DMSO.

Gently mix to avoid bubbles.
Dispense 1 mL of cell suspension into pre-cooled cryovials, labelled with:

Patient name or anonymised ID.
Sample type (PBMC).
Date.

Place cryovials into a pre-cooled controlled-rate freezing container (e.g. Mr Frosty) and transfer to a −70 °C or −80 °C freezer.
After at least overnight freezing, move cryovials to liquid nitrogen for long-term storage.

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Protocol ID: HUM-K562-CULTURE-001
Version: v1.0
Author: Dillon Corvino
Date: 2025-11-21

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 1 – Reagents and medium preparation

Pre-warm complete culture medium:

RPMI 1640

10% FCS

1% Pen/Strep


Pre-warm PBS (if washing is needed).

Label flasks with:

Cell line name (K-562)

Passage number

Date

Operator initials

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 2 – Thawing K-562 cells

Pre-warm 10–15 mL of complete medium to 37 °C.
Thaw a cryovial of K-562 cells in a 37 °C water bath:

Gently swirl and remove when only a small ice crystal remains.

Transfer contents into a 15 mL tube containing 10 mL pre-warmed complete medium.
Centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min at room temperature.
Remove supernatant and gently resuspend the pellet in 10–15 mL fresh complete medium.
Transfer cells to a T25 or T75 flask and incubate at 37 °C, 5% CO₂.







Note



The centrifugation step removes DMSO, preventing toxicity during recovery.

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 3 – Routine culture and passaging

Recommended density

Maintain between 2 × 10⁵ and 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL.



Procedure

Gently resuspend the culture by pipetting up and down.
Count cells using trypan blue or an automated counter.
If density > 1 × 10⁶ cells/mL:

Split culture 1:2 to 1:5 depending on growth.

Add fresh, pre-warmed complete medium to adjust culture to:

2–3 × 10⁵ cells/mL

Return to incubator (37 °C, 5% CO₂).







Warning



Do not allow cultures to sit for more than 3–4 days without splitting. Nutrient depletion leads to apoptosis and growth arrest.

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 4 – Short-term storage / holding conditions

Cultures may be held at 2–4 × 10⁵ cells/mL for 24–48 h without splitting.
If cultures appear slow or viability drops:

Increase medium volume

Spin down and resuspend in entirely fresh medium

title: K-562 Cell Line Culture Protocol
text:
Step 5 – Cryopreservation of K-562 cells

Preparation of freezing medium

90% FCS + 10% DMSO
(or use BUF-GEN-FREEZE-MIX-001 diluted 1:1 with cell suspension)



Freezing procedure

Collect cells in exponential growth phase.
Centrifuge at 300 g for 5 min.
Resuspend in freezing medium at 1–10 × 10⁶ cells/mL.
Aliquot 1 mL into labelled cryovials.
Place vials into a controlled-rate freezing container (e.g. Mr Frosty).
Freeze at −70/−80 °C overnight.
Transfer vials to liquid nitrogen for long-term storage.
